Supported Pt catalysts are widely applied for the hydrogenation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, but it remains a challenge to achieve deep hydrogenation with high atomic utilization. Herein, a novel approach that combines physical vapor deposition with ozonation treatment was developed to construct the highly dispersed Pt on HY zeolite. The high concentration of O3 was utilized to remove the ligand of acetylacetone platinum under mild condition due to its strong oxidizing properties, which markedly inhibited the aggregation of the Pt species. The hydrogenation of naphthalene and anthracene was investigated on such catalysts and compared with the catalyst prepared by traditional calcination approach, it was found that the co-existence of Pt single-atom and cluster on HY of 1Pt/HY-O3 exhibited significantly high catalytic performance in the hydrogenation of naphthalene and anthracene, which was beneficiated from the synergistic effect of Pt single-atoms and clusters on HY support. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Naphthalene Hydrogenation Ozonation Traditional calcination Particle size distribution Pt/HY Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Supported noble metal as hydrogenation catalysts have been widely used in the chemical industry. However, the scarce reserves and high cost of noble metals greatly limit their catalytic application. In recent years, noble metal single-atom and cluster catalysts have attracted wide attention due to their high atomic utilization [1,2], and the excellent catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of aldehyde [3,4], alkyne [5,6], and olefin [7,8], etc. The synthetic methodologies for fabricating highly dispersed noble metal catalysts mainly focused on: (1) Defect engineering, which is to create defect vacancies on the surface of the support to strengthen the interaction between the support and metal ions [9–14]. (2) Doping strategy. The heteroatom (N, P, S, etc.) is introduced to adjust the electronic, and chemical properties as well as surface structure of the support to regulate the interaction between the support and the metal [15–20]. (3) Spatial confinement strategy. Porous solid materials (such as MOF, zeolite, etc.) are usually used to encapsulate the active components for inhibiting their aggregation [21–27]. As less complicated chemical modification is required, this method is widely used. Unlike the hydrogenation of small molecules over single-atom catalyst, the deep hydrogenation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons often required active sites with poly-atoms due to their large molecular dimensions. [28,29] Typically, the metal catalyst with large particles can effectively hydrogenate large molecules, but it will seriously reduce the utilization of metal atoms. For this reason, it is necessary to develop a new generation catalyst with a good balance between the particle size and the activation of large polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. Zeolite is an ideal packaging material to stabilize metal clusters because of its high thermal stability, chemical stability, high surface area, and robust microporous structure [30,31]. Conventional methods, such as wetting impregnation, are typically used to introduce metals into the channels of zeolite due to their simplicity [32]. However, under the influence of solvent surface tension, it is easily deposited as aggregate on the support surface [33,34]. Physical vapor deposition (PVD) is an effective method to allow the introduction of precursors of active metals into micropores. And organometallic compounds (such as Pt(acac)2) are good candidate precursors due to their small size and ease of sublimation [35]. Due to the high surface energy of Pt single atoms or clusters, it is prone to migrate and agglomerate during the following calcination at high temperatures for removing ligands [36–38]. Thus, the removal of ligands coordinated with Pt under mild condition is particularly required to construct a catalyst with highly dispersed Pt on the support. However, most work regarding the catalysis of metal species has focused on the size and/or morphology feature, the removal of organic-residue from the metal species and avoiding undesirable side effects has been seldom discussed. Among the various removal methods, O3 has received a broad attention for its chemical stability, nontoxicity, and excellent oxidability. Such new strategy that combines excitation by PVD with the oxidation by ozone was applied to eliminate the ligand of Pt(acac)2 under ambient conditions, making ozonation-treatment a promising technology for the removal of organic residue. Naphthalene and anthracene are important polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons that were produced as byproducts in the coal coking industry, and their hydrogenation products are widely used in the chemical industry [39]. For example, naphthalene can be transformed into high-value-added tetralin and decalin by hydrogenation. Decalin has cis- and trans- isomers, of which cis-decalin can be used to make high-performance plasticizers, and trans-decalin can be used as an important additive in aviation kerosene. Numerous efforts had been made to enhance the efficiency of hydrogenation of polycyclic aromatics. In this work, we developed a novel method that combines the advantages of PVD and ozonation to fabricate highly dispersed platinum catalysts. The metal complex Pt(acac)2 as a precursor was introduced into the channels of HY through the PVD method. A high concentration of ozone was applied to decompose the organic ligands. Owing to its strong oxidability, ligand removal can be carried out under mild conditions. With this treatment, the Pt atoms were strongly anchored on the channel of zeolite, making it difficult to agglomerate. Based on this synthetic approach, a range of supported Pt catalysts with the size from single atoms to clusters, and to nanoparticles was obtained. The structure and properties of the synthetic catalysts were finely characterized using a series of technologies. The deep hydrogenations of naphthalene and anthracene were tested on such Pt/HY catalysts with various sizes of Pt to reveal the relationship between the size of Pt species and catalytic performance, it has been found that the coexistence of Pt single atoms and clusters on HY contributes to the high catalytic efficiency. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Naphthalene (C10H8, ≥ 98 %), Anthracene (C14H10, ≥ 98 %), n-decane (C10H22, ≥ 98 %), n-octane (C8H18, >99 %), and acetylacetone platinum (C10H14O4Pt, 97 %) were purchased from Aladdin. HY (SiO2/Al2O3=5.4) was purchased from Tianjin Nan Hua Catalyst Co., Ltd. Anhydrous ethanol (C2H6O, ≥ 99.7 %) was purchased from Tianjin Tian li Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation In a typical synthesis, a certain amount of Pt(acac)2 and HY were immersed in an ethanol solution at 50 °C for 3 h and then dried at 90 °C for 10 h. After that, the powder sample was transferred to a sealed tube and heated at 70 °C, maintaining the pressure below 500 μmHg for 1 h, then the temperature was raised to 90 °C and kept at this temperature for 10 h to remove the solvent in the HY channels. Then, the temperature was further increased to 130 °C and kept at this temperature for 3 h to obtain the Pt(acac)2 @HY. To remove the ligand, the Pt(acac)2@HY was treated by the ozonation process, as schemed in Fig. S1, a certain amount of Pt(acac)2@HY was loaded into the quartz tube connected to the ozone generator. The sample was heated at 100 °C for 3 h under a high concentration of O3. The obtained catalysts were denoted as xPt/HY-O3 (x represents the theoretical Pt loading, and O3 represents ozonation). For comparison, part of Pt(acac)2@HY was treated by the traditional calcination at 300 °C for 3 h to remove the ligand, and the catalysts were assigned to xPt/HY-C (C referred to calcination). Before the hydrogenation experiment, the catalyst was reduced under the flow of 10 vol%H2/Ar at 300 °C for 3 h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The specific surface area and pore parameters of the catalysts were measured by Micromeritics ASAP 2020, PLUS HD88 at 77.4 K through nitrogen adsorption, before measurement, the catalyst was degassed for 10 h at 130 °C to avoid Pt(acac)2 decomposition. X-ray diffraction (XRD) were collected on a MiniFlexⅡ desktop X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) with the CuK α source (λ = 0.15418 nm), the scanning range is 5°–80 °. The actual Pt loading in the catalysts were analyzed and measured by inductively coupled plasma spectrometry (Leeman Labs Profile ICP, Agilent 725 ICP-OES/Agilent 7700). The ligand removal of Pt(acac)2 was analyzed by thermogravimetric mass spectrometry (TG-MS), Thermal gravimetric analysis (TG) spectra were performed with a Setaram Evolution 16/18 thermogravimetric analyzer coupled to a mass spectrometer (OMNIstar/quadrupole mass analyzer; Pfeiffer vacuum). Temperature-programmed carbon monoxide desorption (CO-TPD), hydrogen temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), and temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) were measured by Micromeritics AutoChem Ⅱ 2920. Before the characterization, the catalyst (50 mg) was thermal treated at 300 °C in Ar flows (30 mL/min) for 1 h. and cooled to 50 °C and exposed to mixed 5 vol%O2/He or 5 vol%H2/Ar gas (40 mL/min) for 30 min, followed purged with pure He or Ar (30 mL/min) for 40 min to remove the physisorbed O2 or H2 molecule. Finally, the sample was heated from 50 °C to 550 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C /min and recorded by a TCD detector. The in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (CO-DRIFT) experiments were performed on a Bruker INVENIO R spectrometer equipped with a Harrick Scientific DRIFTS cell. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was performed using JEM-2100 F with accelerating voltage of 200 kV. XPS (Axis Ultra DLD, Kratos, UK) was used to analyze the valence state of Pt species on the sample surface. UV–vis absorption spectra were taken on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 750 UV/Vis/NIR spectrometer with BaSO4 as a standard reflector. The pulse chemisorption experiment of CO was carried out by using the Micromeritics Auto Chem Ⅱ 2920 chemisorption instrument. The surface Pt number of atoms was calculated according to the adsorption amount of CO based on the assumption of CO/Pt= 2. First-principles calculations were carried out in the framework of the DFT using the Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package (CASTEP). The naphthalene molecule layer on the Pt surface was added to establish the adsorption interface models for the property analysis. 2.4 Catalytic experiments The evaluation of naphthalene and anthracene hydrogenation was carried out in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave with a PTFE lining. 0.05 mol/L naphthalene solution and 0.01 mol/L anthracene solution were prepared using n-decane as solvent and n-octane as internal standard. Before the reaction, 5 mL of reaction liquid and 20 mg of catalyst are added to the above reactor, purging 5 times with high-purity H2, and then the H2 pressure was raised to 3 MPa and the temperature was kept at the needed value for definite time with a stirring rate of 500 rpm. The quantitative analysis of products was conducted on gas chromatography (Shimadzu 2010 pro, FID detector, and DB-5-HT column). The conversion, selectivity, yield, and TOF (turnover frequency) were calculated as following equations. Conversion = mole of reactant begin − mole of reactant end mole of reactant begin × 100 % Selectivity of target product = mole of target product mole of all products × 100 % Yield of target product = Selectivity of target product × Conversion TOF ( h − 1 ) = Number of converted feed molecules Number of surface Pt atoms × reaction time 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and ligand removal The synthesis process of the catalyst is shown in Scheme 1. After the impregnation, the following PVD treatment allowed the Pt(acac)2 (molecular size: 0.50 nm × 0.65 nm) to enter into the HY channels (12-membered ring pore, 0.74 nm), improving the dispersion of Pt. And the ozonation process was chosen to mildly remove the ligand to inhibit the growth of Pt atoms. In addition, the introduction of Pt species into the HY channels was demonstrated by a shape-selective reaction. As the size selectivity of the HY zeolite, the Pt atoms located in channels of HY zeolites displayed different hydrogenation activity of cyclohexene (Converssion ∼100 %, molecular size: 0.53 nm × 0.53 nm) and cyclododecene (Converssion <5 %, molecular size: 0.93 nm × 0.93 nm) (Table S1). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm ( Fig. 1a) revealed the textural properties of the samples. The adsorption capacity of the HY, 1Pt/HY-C, and 1Pt/HY-O3 samples increased sharply over the range of 0–0.2 of relative pressure (P/P0), exhibiting the typical type I isotherm. According to the IUPAC classification, this represents microporous structures [40], and the XRD spectra of all samples only showed the patterns of HY zeolite (Fig. 1b), indicating that the synthesis process did not damage the pore structures. Table S2 showed that the specific surface area (SBET), microporous area (Smic), and microporous volume (Vmic) of the 1Pt(acac)2 @HY decreased compared to HY zeolite, illustrating the introduction of Pt(acac)2 into the zeolite channels. When the ligand was removed by ozonation or calcination, the pore volumes and surface areas were largely recovered (Table S2). 1Pt/HY-C had a larger Smic and Vmic than 1Pt/HY-O3, suggesting that the Pt in 1Pt/HY-C had a large particle size and migrated out of the micropores due to high-temperature calcination. In contrast, the Pt in 1Pt/HY-O3 was high dispersed in the micropores, as evidence by the low porosity. The high-temperature calcination can sufficiently remove the metallic ligand but may trigger the aggregation of active metals. Thus, ligand removal at low temperatures is favored. In this study, we tried to decompose the ligand of Pt(acac)2 with the assistance of O3 oxidation. A high concentration of O3 (30 %) generated by electrolyzing water made the ligand to be oxidized and decomposed at low temperatures, which inhibited the migration and agglomeration of Pt species. However, high concentrations of O3 have the risk of explosion at high temperatures [41,42], so caution must be taken about O3 treatment temperature. We compared the reaction results over ozonized catalysts treated at different temperature and time, and determined the optimal conditions was 100 °C and 3 h. To investigate the ligand decomposition by the ozonation, the Pt(acac)2 @HY samples before and after ozone treatment were characterized with TG-MS under an air atmosphere. Considering the very low loading of Pt(acac)2 (Pt ∼1 %), it was inaccurate to confirm the loss of organic species directly from TG profiles. Mass loss from decomposition of organic are overshadowed by the water loss of the catalysts. The Pt(acac)2 @HY precursor showed noticeable mass losses and MS signal of CO2 (130 °C) and H2O (280 °C), attributing to dehydration and ligand decomposition (Fig. 1c). In fact, the detection limit of MS is much lower than that of TG. Based on this, the organic residues are usually analyzed by MS results. Therefore, the calcination temperature for preparing Pt/HY-C was determined to be 300 °C, which was deemed to achieve the complete decomposition of Pt precursor. As shown in Fig. 1d, almost no CO2 signal was detected for the sample treated with ozone, and the mass loss was attributed to the desorption of water. This result proved that the ligand in Pt(acac)2 was removed by ozonation at 100 °C for 3 h. The XPS spectra of Pt/HY-O3 revealed that ozone oxidized Pt2+ to Pt4+ during the decomposition of the ligand (Fig. S2a). Meanwhile, Pt/HY-C exhibited a coexistence of Pt2+ and Pt0 (24.1 % and 75.9 %, respectively) after calcination at 300 °C (Fig. S2b). This suggests that the ligand pyrolysis of Pt(acac)2 resulted in the partial reduction of Pt2+ species even under an air atmosphere. For the calcination treatment, the ligand decomposition resulted in CO, CO2, and H2O. And CO could reduce the Pt2+ to Pt0 species, which were unstable and merged to form large agglomerates at high temperatures. While for ozonation treatment, O3 was decomposed at 100 °C to produce an active oxygen atom with strong oxidability, which promoted the decomposition of ligands and the oxidization of Pt2+ to Pt4+. 3.2 The property characterization of catalysts and HY support The chemical valence states and relative contents of surficial Pt species in the pre-reduced catalysts were obtained by XPS peak deconvolution ( Fig. 2a and 2b). The characteristic peaks for Pt0 species had binding energies around 71.34 and 74.67 eV, while those for Pt2+ species were around 72.70 and 76.03 eV [43]. Al 2p species had characteristic peaks around 75.14 eV [44]. The reduced catalysts contained 65.8 % Pt0 and 34.2 % Pt2+ for 1Pt/HY-O3, and 85.7 % Pt0 and 14.3 % Pt2+ for 1Pt/HY-C. The relative content of Pt2+ species present in 1Pt/HY-O3 was 19.9 % more than that in 1Pt/HY-C. It is known that PtOx clusters could be reduced to Pt0 species by H2, whereas Ptδ+(0 < δ < 2) species strongly coordinated with O or N on the support were more stable and were difficult to be reduced [45,46]. The XPS spectra demonstrated that the PVD-Ozonation method can obtain more stable Pt-O species in the reduced catalysts, they formed single atom states with about +2 valence. The CO was often used as the probe molecule to investigate the properties of active centers. Here the surficial properties of reduced catalysts were investigated by CO-TPD (Fig. 2c). And the total desorption amount of CO calculated by the peak areas were 0.74, 0.99, and 1.17 mmol/g for HY, 1Pt/HY-C, and 1Pt/HY-O3, respectively. The pure HY support exhibits two CO desorption peaks at 190 °C and 270 °C. And two extra CO desorption peaks were observed for 1Pt/HY-C located at 337 °C and 370 °C respectively. Three extra desorption peaks were found for 1Pt/HY-O3 located at 105 °C, 305 °C, and 370 °C respectively. These extra peaks could be attributed to the CO adsorbed on Pt species. The CO-TPD illustrated that 1Pt/HY-O3 can provide more reaction sites than 1Pt/HY-C. And the CO desorption peaks at different temperatures represent the different adsorption strengths. The smaller Pt particles exhibit weaken adsorption capacity for CO than the large ones, leading to low CO desorption temperature and more CO adsorption amount [47,48]. The weak CO adsorption for 1Pt/HY-O3 (105 °C peak) may attribute to the Pt-O species with + 2 valence. And the strong adsorption (305–370 °C) can be ascribed to the metallic Pt species. These results suggest that ozonation is a more effective method to prepare high-dispersion noble catalysts than traditional calcination. The H2-TPD experiment was performed to investigate the hydrogen adsorption and activation on the catalyst surface (Fig. 2d). It was observed that contrary to CO adsorption, H2 was hardly adsorbed on the pristine HY support (0.078 mmol/g). The Pt-based catalysts displays a main reduction peak centered at ∼170 °C, which is assigned to the strongly dissociation of hydrogen. This points out that hydrogen was mainly activated on the Pt. After subtraction of H2 adsorbed on HY zeolite, the amount of H2 adsorbed on Pt species over 1Pt/HY-O3 (0.272 mmol/g) was calculated to be 1.3 times higher than that on 1Pt/HY-C (0.223 mmol/g), confirming the high Pt dispersion of 1Pt/HY-O3 catalyst. The desorption temperature reflects the activation degree of hydrogen. Typically, the large Pt particles lead to weaker binding to the hydrogen molecules, which is detrimental to its activation [49]. At higher-temperature region, 1Pt/HY-O3 showed desorption at 366 °C, compared to 347 °C of 1Pt/HY-C, indicating that the Pt-H bond over 1Pt/HY-O3 is stronger, which facilitates the total dissociation of hydrogen and provides a large number of activated H atoms during the hydrogenation process. The enhancement of the hydrogen dissociation demonstrates that the Pt2+ single atom can be efficiently activation of hydrogen. CO-DRIFTS was used to explore the surface Pt species of reduced Pt/HY catalysts ( Fig. 3a). Linear adsorption and bridge adsorption of CO on Pt clusters and nanoparticles can be identified by the vibration peaks around 2085 cm−1 and 1860 cm−1, respectively [50,51]. It was found that the bridge adsorption peak was absent and linear adsorption was dominant. The peaks of CO adsorbed on Pt single atoms, including multi-carbonyl (Ptδ+(CO)n) and mono-carbonyl (Ptδ+(CO)) species, were located at the higher wave number in the range of 2095 cm−1 to 2200 cm−1 [52,53]. The CO-DRIFT of Pt(acac)2/HY precursors were conducted. The adsorption bands of CO on Pt single atoms can be apparently observed. (Fig. S3) For 1Pt/HY-O3, the adsorption bands of CO on Pt single atoms can be apparently observed, meantime the main peak was broadened over the range of single atoms and clusters, suggesting their coexistence. The percentage of exposed Pt single atoms (82.4 %) was obtained for 1Pt/HY-O3 catalyst via deconvolution of CO-DRIFTS. (Fig. S4) However, only the adsorption peak of CO on Pt clusters was observed for 1Pt/HY-C, suggesting almost no CO adsorption on single atomic Pt. The particle distribution of Pt species was further examined using HRTEM (Figs. 3b, 3c), small and regular Pt clusters were observed on 1Pt/HY-O3, however, the single atom Pt cannot be discerned at this resolution. Statistical analysis performed on around 50 Pt nanoparticles in 1Pt/HY-O3 catalyst displayed the size of Pt clusters with about 1.3 nm, such sizes obtained from TEM images is often higher than its actual particle size owing to the distortions caused by the cumulative effect and defocusing [54]. Whereas larger Pt particles appeared on 1Pt/HY-C, indicating that high temperature (300 °C) leads to Pt aggregation. According to the above characterizations, it was revealed that mild ozonation can effectively inhibit Pt aggregation to obtain highly Pt dispersed 1Pt/HY-O3 due to the strong interaction of high valence Pt4+ with the HY support. The coexistence of Pt single atoms and small clusters is the character of the catalyst prepared by the PVD-Ozonation method. After H2 reduction, XPS showed 34.2 % of Pt2+ and 65.8 % of Pt0, which were tentatively attributed to Pt single atoms and Pt clusters, respectively. On the contrary, the calcination mainly leads to the formation of large Pt particles of 1Pt/HY-C, obtaining a high percentage of Pt0 of 85.7 % after reduction. 3.3 Catalytic performance in the hydrogenation of polycyclic aromatics The catalytic performance of 1Pt/HY catalysts for naphthalene hydrogenation were shown in Fig. 4a. The conversion of naphthalene and the yield of decalin reach 99.9 % and 75.1 % for the 1Pt/HY-O3 catalyst, respectively, significantly higher than those of 40.5 % and 5.8 % for 1Pt/HY-C at low reaction temperature (50 °C) for 1 h. Compared with Pt/HY-PVD, after the Pt(acac)2 impregnated on HY support, Pt/HY-NPVD had the poor naphthalene hydrogenation catalytic performance under reaction conditions (Table. S3). The XRD pattern of Pt/HY-NPVD catalysts exhibited the diffraction peaks assigned to Pt(111), indicating that the Pt species without pore-limiting were highly aggregated at high temperature (300 °C, 10 vol%H2/Ar) (Fig. S5). The high atom utilization and an appropriate proportion of Pt2+ and Pt0 species in the 1Pt/HY-O3 catalyst contribute to its excellent performance. The Pt2+ single atom with electron deficiency dominated the hydrogen activation, where the unoccupied d orbital is favorable for the adsorption and activation of H2, the determined step in the hydrogenation of polycyclic aromatics [55]. Meanwhile, the deep hydrogenation to decalin may need the activation of naphthalene and tetralin over the planar Pt clusters. In addition, the reusability of 1Pt/HY-O3 in naphthalene hydrogenation was examined (Fig. S6). Decalin yield showed a slight decrease in three consecutive reactions, indicating the catalyst's moderate stability. The hydrogenation ability of 1Pt/HY-O3 catalyst was further explored through anthracene deep hydrogenation. Anthracene activation is more difficult than naphthalene and its hydrogenation activity is lower under the same reaction conditions (Table S4). However, the 1Pt/HY-O3 catalyst (12.1 %) demonstrates significantly improved catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of anthracene, which is much higher than the 1Pt/HY-C catalyst (< 1 %). When the anthracene conversion reached 100 % by regulating the reaction conditions, the yield of perhydroanthracene on 1Pt/HY-O3 was 99.6 %, significantly higher than the 58.5 % of 1Pt/HY-C, and there are no ring opening products were detected by GC-MS (Fig. 4b). The hydrogenation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (anthracene) is carried out in a specific order. The first-ring hydrogenation of PAHs is the most favored, and the hydrogenation of subsequent rings becomes more and more difficult. Conversion of anthracene into di-hydro and tetra-hydro derivatives can be easily achieved even under low catalytic activity, but further conversions to octa-hydro, and per-hydro anthracene depend on the activity of catalysts. With the Pt loading increased from 0.5 % to 2.5 %, the yields of perhydroanthracene on Pt/HY-O3 were higher than those on corresponding Pt/HY-C. This further validates the significant advantages of the PVD-Ozonation method. The adsorption of naphthalene and tetralin of catalyst was further explored through UV–vis spectra ( Fig. 5a, b). The ultraviolet response of naphthalene centered at ∼270 nm displayed a significant decrease after adding Pt/HY-C catalysts introduce to solution, while 1Pt/HY-O3 catalyst showed a slight decrease. It deduced that naphthalene with large planar structures were prone to adsorb on Pt nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. 3, the 1Pt/HY-C had much greater size Pt particle size than 1Pt/HY-O3, consequently, the adsorption amount of naphthalene on 1Pt/HY-C is obviously stronger than that on 1Pt/HY-O3. Tetralin has a single aromatic ring, its structural sensibility is not such obvious. So, 1Pt/HY-C, and 1Pt/HY-O3 maintain similar absorption intensity in Fig. 5b. The UV–vis spectra of tetralin from 1Pt/HY-C, and 1Pt/HY-O3 had shift which may be caused by the introduction of the catalyst. The acidity of the Pt/HY-O3 and Pt/HY-C catalysts were determined by NH3-TPD (Fig. S7), exhibiting the similar amount of ammonia adsorbed. Indeed, the acid properties of the catalyst may not directly correlate with the preparation of catalysts. The main reason for the difference in hydrogenation performance is the adsorption capacity of reactants in the active centers of Pt species with different particle size. The adsorption of naphthalene (reactant) on Pt species were further investigate by density functional theory calculations (DFT) (Fig. 5c, d). The naphthalene molecule were adsorbed in a horizontal adsorption mode on Pt single sites with adsorption energy (Eads) of −0.48 eV, and behaved on Pt(111) surface with Eads of −2.04 eV. Combing the experimental and calculated results, it was reasonable to believe that the electron-rich aromatic ring can be easily adsorbed on planar active centers containing several atoms. 3.4 Effect of Pt particle size on catalytic performance With the Pt loading increased from 0.5 % to 2.5 %, the yields of decalin on Pt/HY-O3 were higher than those on corresponding Pt/HY-C catalysts (Table S5). The Pt loadings of the samples before and after PVD were investigated by ICP, which showed that only a minimal amount of Pt is loss during the PVD process (Table S6). The hydrogenation performance shows that the PVD-Ozonation method offers significant advantages over a wide range of Pt loadings. The supported metal catalysts usually consist of ill-defined catalytic sites such that the reaction may undergo different catalytic pathways at different sites. The effect of Pt particle size on the hydrogenation activity was investigated by using a series of Pt/HY-O3 catalysts with different Pt loading. CO-DRIFTS ( Fig. 6a) showed that as Pt loading increased, bands representing CO on Pt single atoms on Pt/HY-O3 catalyst gradually disappeared, while the peak involving CO on Pt clusters increased, and no bridge adsorption peak of CO was observed. The Pt/HY-O3 with different Pt loadings were observed by TEM images (Fig. 3b and Fig. 6). The Pt species of 0.5Pt/HY-O3 showing a high proportion of Pt single atoms collected by HAADF-STEM (Fig. 6e). As Pt loading increased, the particle size of Pt also increased correspondingly. And the 1Pt/HY-O3 exhibited the coexistence of single atoms and cluster, which is agreement with HRTEM and CO-DRIFTS results (Fig. 6f). It can also be observed that as the Pt loading is larger than 1 % the size of Pt species distributed over some extent from single atom to nanoparticle ( Fig. 7a). It can be concluded that with Pt loadings up to 2.5 %, the PVD-Ozonation method is significantly advantageous in preparing highly dispersed noble catalysts. This method enables the creation of catalysts with different particle sizes by varying the Pt loading, which is difficult to achieve using the traditional calcination method. The naphthalene hydrogenation TOF (Turnover Frequency) of catalysts was studied at conversion rates below 20 % to determine the intrinsic activity of the catalyst [49,56]. Fig. 7b. showed the TOF for a range of Pt/HY-O3 catalysts with different Pt loading. The TOF value presents a volcanic trend with the increase of Pt loading (Table S7). The 0.5Pt/HY-O3 catalyst containing mainly single atoms had the lowest TOF (356 h−1), indicating the weak activity for the naphthalene hydrogenation. Tailoring the precise functioning of the active sites with respect to many different parameters is the one we must overcome to preparation of high-performance catalysts. It is generally believed that H2 activation and naphthalene adsorption are the limiting rate step for hydrogenation reactions [57], and Pt single atoms can hardly provide several active centers with a weaken ability to adsorption of naphthalene. When the loading increased to 1 %, the catalyst had the highest activity with a TOF of 1433 h−1 due to the co-existence of the Pt single atom and clusters which provide synergistic effects of activation of H2 and adsorption of naphthalene. However, as the Pt loading further increased, Pt nanoparticles were formed and grew, as revealed by the TEM and CO-DRIFT, leading to the TOF decrease continually. It was found that the oversized metal particles affected hydrogen activation negatively [46]. The formation of large nanoparticles reduced Pt dispersion, decreasing the number of active centers. The reported catalytic results of naphthalene hydrogenation over zeolite supported Pt or Pd catalysts were listed in Table S8. It could be seen the Pt/HY-O3 exhibited much high deep hydrogenation performance towards naphthalene under very mild reaction conditions. As for the adsorption and hydrogenation of naphthalene, the electron-rich aromatic ring tends to be adsorbed on planar active centers with nano-/cluster sizes. In addition, the positively charged Pt species have high suitability to provide the hydrogen proton [55]. In this situation, hydrogenation occurred by the H spillover. But owing to the weak adsorption and activation for naphthalene, usually only part hydrogenated intermediates were obtained. This can only be fulfilled on the Pt clusters or nanoparticles. The stable adsorption of polycyclic aromatics is important for their sufficient activation to achieve deep hydrogenation. Therefore, the highest naphthalene hydrogenation activity of 1Pt/HY-O3 can be ascribed to the following causes. (1) The optimal proportion of Pt single atoms and clusters, (2) the high activity of Pt single atom and cluster for H2 activation and the deep hydrogenation of naphthalene, (3) the synergy between adsorption of the naphthalene and the spillover of H atoms derived from Pt species, which is an interesting observation that has not been reported in the literature yet. The proposed mechanism of the hydrogenation of naphthalene at 1Pt/HY-O3 catalyst is depicted in Scheme 2. The electron-deficient Pt single atoms are conducive to the dissociation of hydrogen, while the Pt clusters, obtained through high reduction temperature (10 vol%H2/Ar, 300 °C) play a major function in the adsorption of naphthalene. And the activated hydrogen reduces the adsorbed naphthalene to tetralin intermediate. For further reduction to deep hydrogenation product of decalin. Sufficient activation by the planar stable adsorption of tetralin or decalin was required, which can only occur on the Pt clusters. The activated H atoms generated are utilized for the hydrogenation of naphthalene to tetralin in the first step. Subsequently, tetralin is planar stable adsorbed on the Pt clusters with more active sites, making it effectively activated in the high concentration of H atoms to generate decalin. As for the consecutive hydrogenation process of naphthalene, the synergistic effect of appropriate proportions of Pt single atoms and small clusters improved the deep hydrogenation efficiency of naphthalene. 4 Conclusions We developed a novel method combining PVD and ozonation to fabricate polycyclic aromatic hydrogenation catalysts with highly dispersed Pt on HY zeolite. The success of our method relied on the Pt(acac)2 metal complex being introduced to the channel of zeolite by the PVD method, then the acac ligand was removed by ozonation under mild condition. Unlike high-temperature treatment by calcination in air, the high concentration of O3 with strong oxidizing ability could significantly remove ligands at only about 100 ℃, markedly inhibiting the Pt aggregation. In the deep hydrogenation of naphthalene and anthracene, it was found that 1Pt/HY-O3 catalyst featuring Pt single atom and small cluster exhibited much higher catalytic activity than Pt single-atom or Pt nanoparticle catalysts. The H2 could be effectively activated over Pt single atom, leading to high hydrogenation activity. Although polycyclic aromatics can be adsorbed and activated on Pt species, the deep hydrogenation of polycyclic aromatic needs the planar active centers which can only be provided by Pt cluster and nanoparticles. Our finding throw light on the design and synthesis of high-efficient catalysts for such complicated hydrogenation reactions. coredata.dc:description: Supported Pt catalysts are widely applied for the hydrogenation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, but it remains a challenge to achieve deep hydrogenation with high atomic utilization. Herein, a novel approach that combines physical vapor deposition with ozonation treatment was developed to construct the highly dispersed Pt on HY zeolite. The high concentration of O3 was utilized to remove the ligand of acetylacetone platinum under mild condition due to its strong oxidizing properties, which markedly inhibited the aggregation of the Pt species. The hydrogenation of naphthalene and anthracene was investigated on such catalysts and compared with the catalyst prepared by traditional calcination approach, it was found that the co-existence of Pt single-atom and cluster on HY of 1Pt/HY-O3 exhibited significantly high catalytic performance in the hydrogenation of naphthalene and anthracene, which was beneficiated from the synergistic effect of Pt single-atoms and clusters on HY support.
coredata.dc:title: Ozonation assisted synthesis of well-dispersed Pt on HY zeolite as highly efficient catalyst for deep hydrogenation of naphthalene
